title: The man who taught David Hockney to let his hair down
text:
A youthful encounter with ‘the wild man of abstraction’ was the making of Britain’s favourite artist, says Mark Hudson

One spring afternoon in 1958, a young art student sporting NHS glasses and a pudding-basin haircut walked into a room at the Wakefield Art Gallery. He took one look at the big, bold, furiously expressive abstract paintings that crowded the walls – the work of the Scottish artist Alan Davie – and immediately changed his view on everything art could, and should, be.

“This,” says David Hockney still smiling at the recollection of that day over 60 years later, “was MODERN ART. The teaching at the art school in Bradford, where I was a student, was very traditional. I’m grateful...
